subs.text: May 11

@jprupp @FreightAlley @EricRego8 The refinery issues are apparently diesel-specific (especially re: low-sulfur diesel) and have been building for several years (i.e. pre-pandemic), but to the extent that any kerosene-based fuels are transported by diesel-powered trucks or trains, yes.

subs.text:
@slamastack The only safe tech for this sort of thing is legacy, open-standard tech such as #X10 or #Insteon and the modern (but much more complicated) #Zigbee or proprietary (#Zwave) equivalents.

Worst-case, a hub might have to be replaced. My X-10 switches from the mid-90s still work!

subs.text:
@ImALittleTeaPo9 @TrentTelenko I imagine they can type the coordinates manually into their system. Maybe adds 15 seconds of extra latency?

Creating an automated system link, using modern microcontrollers (that can fit _inside_ of an interface cable) could be prototyped in a day or two.

subs.text:
@nicholrr @TrentTelenko DD-459 was sunk at Guadalcanal.

DD-724 was built two years later, and was also a former USS Laffey.

DD-724 is the museum ship in SC next to the former USS Yorktown*.

(That is CV-10, which itself was a replacement for an earlier â€˜Yorktownâ€™, CV-5, that sank at Midway).

subs.text:
@lithohedron @boondaburrah @errantambition @Foone Theyâ€™re still used by expensive lab hardware such as oscilloscopes, and also in some military equipment.

If you need to quickly move a 50kB file between two air-gapped systems from different vendors, these can be faster, more secure,& lower-overhead than using a USB flash drive.
